channel.title: Development Data Partnership
channel.description: Recent content on Development Data Partnership

item.title: Legal Foundation
item.description: Template data license agreements and MOUs between organizations save time and resources.

item.title: Partnership
item.description: Standard data licenses are signed between the data partner and each participating organization (e.g., World Bank, IMF, IDB).

item.title: Responsible data use
item.description: USAID and Data Collabortives co-corganized an interactve workshop on approaches to responsible data use in international development.

item.title: Short Term Impact
item.description: Since the World Bank launched the beta Data Partnership platform in April 2018 (then called “Data Collaboratives”), more than 100 development projects are now under implementation.

item.title: WHY PARTNERSHIP
item.description: Public policy and provision of public infrastructure and services are heavily dependent on data – higher quality, timely data translates into more effective sector and program prioritization, design, implementation, monitoring, and evaluation.

item.title: Data Partner
item.description: The Partnership unlocks public good opportunities from proprietary data in a secure, responsible manner. Partnerships can be leveraged to open markets in emerging economies, receive new data methods and algorithms, and increase staff skills through collaboration and secondment opportunities.

item.title: Development Partner
item.description: The Partnership is open to donors and entities engaged in international development work. Members have access to the Data Partnership web platform and IT infrastructure and are invited to participate in exchanges and training activities.

item.title: KEY CHALLENGES
item.description: Despite the potential benefits, there are challenges in linking the supply of proprietary data and the demand for these data for public benefit.

item.title: Long Term Impact
item.description: By learning through real project implementation, the Partnership aims to transform proprietary datasets into sustainably generated, sharable insights for improving public sector services and infrastructure in emerging economies.

item.title: Project Proposals
item.description: Data partner uses the Partnership web platform to evaluate proposals for using their data in a project or produce a “data good”.

item.title: Responsible Data Use
item.description: Data governance principles guide best practices for responsible and ethical data use.

item.title: Data Management
item.description: Upon project approval, data are securely and responsibly managed on behalf of all staff through the Partnership IT architecture and procedures.

item.title: Multi-Disciplinary Teams
item.description: Working groups comprised of data engineers, data scientists, sector domain experts, legal counsel, communications specialists, procurement specialists, and others across the member organizations make a complete platform possible.

item.title: OPPORTUNITY
item.description: The Development Data Partnership has been designed to overcome these supply and demand challenges at scale. Specifically, the Partnership: (a) coordinates and aggregates demand on behalf of public actors; (b) links public sector challenges and domain expertise to relevant proprietary data; (c) significantly reduces the transaction costs associated with data sharing; (d) reduces duplication of effort and facilitates collaboration on development of solutions; and (e) increases transparency and accountability for integrating use of proprietary data in public good analytics.

item.title: Data Goods
item.description: Data partners are kept updated through the Partnership web platform of derived data products and produced code.

item.title: Secure IT Architecture
item.description: Centralized IT architecture and processes for ingesting, storing and processing data, as well as for coding collaboration, create economies of scale amongst partners and facilitate secure data use.

item.title: Data Partnership Management
item.description: A web-based partnership management platform ensures the value proposition for data partners is met.

item.title: Data Goods
item.description: Managed, accessible repositories for derived data products and algorithms broaden Partnership impact.

item.title: Mapping entrepreneurs' response to COVID-19 in Latin America and the Caribbean
item.description: Challenge: The social and economic disruption caused by Covid-19 led to numerous challenges to conduct businesses, provide essential services, and attend to the most basic well-being needs around the globe.

item.title: The Effect of COVID-19 Lockdown Measures on Internet Speed
item.description: COVID-19 and the related lockdown measures to prevent the virus’ spread have highlighted how important it is for everyone to have access to reliable and resilient digital infrastructure.

item.title: Examining the Economic Impact of COVID-19 in India through Daily Electricity Consumption and Nighttime Light Intensity
item.description: Challenge: The COVID-19 pandemic has disrupted economic activity in India. When COVID-19 started to spread in India through domestic contagion, the authorities enacted a series of measures to combat the pandemic, including a strict national lockdown from March 25 to May 4 that strongly disrupted economic activity.

item.title: Optimizing Tourism Investments: Identifying Chokepoints and Underperforming Minor Roads in Sri Lanka
item.description: Challenge: Connected and maintained transportation infrastructure are critical to sustainable economic development, but most current estimation methods of road quality are labor, time, and cost intensive.

item.title: Examining the Economic Impact of India’s Zone Classification to contain COVID-19
item.description: Challenge: The COVID-19 pandemic has disrupted economic activity in India. When COVID-19 started to spread in India through domestic contagion, the Indian authorities enacted a series of measures to combat the pandemic, including a strict national lockdown from March 25 to May 4.

item.title: Socioeconomic Impact of COVID-19 in Indonesia
item.description: Challenge: Although there is a widespread awareness of the pandemic, there is a lack of understanding from citizens’ perspective, especially behaviors it triggers, sentiments towards government as well as rising concerns.

item.title: A Light Primer to Spark / Databricks
item.description: Databricks is a powerful platform for using Spark, a powerful data technology. If you’re reading this, you’re likely a Python or R developer who begins their Spark journey to process large datasets.

item.title: Estimating High-speed Broadband Coverage in Ukraine
item.description: Challenge: Ukraine, Europe’s biggest country, has over 1,192 operators and providers, of which close to three quarters operate under a special preferential tax regime, allowing them not to report their coverage/subscription data to the national telecom regulatory authority.

item.title: 2020 Inspire Challenge Finalist - The ClimaCell Locust Project
item.description: Ag Observatory in collaboration with the World Bank Data Lab guided and facilitated Climacell’s entry into the CGIAR Big Data Inspire Challenge 2020.

item.title: Economic Anxiety and COVID-19 in Southeast Asia
item.description: Challenge: The COVID-19 pandemic has affected the global economy through lockdowns, disrupted supply chains and uncertain economic outlooks. Swift reaction by policy makers are required to prevent a deep recession.

item.title: Analyzing Spatial Accessibility of Health Facilities in Indonesia and Philippines
item.description: Challenge: Indonesia and the Philippines are archipelagos, where geographic and administrative boundaries are similar. The collection of islands is home to different concentrations of ethnic, cultural, linguistic, and socioeconomic groups, with an imbalanced distribution of health facilities and physicians.

item.title: Mapbox Releases a New Movement Dataset for Mobility Insights
item.description: Following the Development Data Partnership launch event at the World Bank-IMF Annual Meetings, Mapbox announces a new dataset on movement data for mobility insights.

item.title: Data Partnership: Bridging the Data Gap for Public Good
item.description: Download Event Program High frequency, timely, and granular information – which is routinely collected by the private sector–can help inform public policy and service delivery.

item.title: Tackling COVID-19 Second Wave using Facebook Mobility Data in Vietnam
item.description: Challenge: On July 24, after 99 days of zero community-transmitted COVID-19 infections, a 57 year-old man tested positive in Danang, a major city in central Vietnam with close to 1.

item.title: Assessing Social Inequality and Lockdown Policies using Mobile Location Data in Indonesia
item.description: Challenge: Lockdown policies such as stay-at-home orders and non-essential business closures are central to fighting the novel coronavirus. However, policy makers are having a hard time answering key questions about their efficacy.

item.title: Introducing the Data Partnership on GitHub
item.description: After launching in 2019, when the Inter-American Development Bank and the International Monetary Fund joined the initiave, the Development Data Partnership has scaled up fast, with more than 100 projects having been brought to life supported by partnerships with more than 20 companies.

item.title: Leveraging New Data Methods to Address an Ancient Challenge: Locusts
item.description: Challenge: The worst locust upsurge in at least 25 years is hitting parts of Africa, the Arabian Peninsula and Western Asia, and over 40 million people who are already food insecure find their food supply and livelihoods threatened.

item.title: How to Find Population Movement Data for Your Country: The Mobile Location Data Inventory
item.description: As the COVID-19 pandemic continues, so have measures to mitigate its spread. Physical distancing and movement restrictions – such as school and workplace closures, public event cancellations, stay-at-home orders, and international and domestic travel bans – vary considerably across countries.

item.title: Mobile Location Data Inventory
item.description: var divElement = document.getElementById('viz1593018616750'); var vizElement = divElement.getElementsByTagName('object')[0]; if(divElement.offsetWidth 800) { vizElement.style.width = '1100px'; vizElement.

item.title: Mobile Location Data Inventory
item.description: var divElement = document.getElementById('viz1593016125962'); var vizElement = divElement.getElementsByTagName('object')[0]; if(divElement.offsetWidth 800) { vizElement.style.width = '1100px'; vizElement.

item.title: Google, Apple, and Facebook: Understanding Mobility during Social Distancing with Private Sector Data
item.description: As countries around the world work to contain the spread and impact of COVID-19, the World Bank Group is moving quickly to provide fast, flexible responses to help developing countries strengthen their pandemic response and health care systems.

item.title: Addressing COVID-19 through Public-Private Data Partnerships -- Where Do We Put New Testing Facilities?
item.description: Background As the COVID-19 pandemic evolves, the World Bank is ramping up its response to help countries around the world. The Bank recently announced $14 billion emergency support program, for which a key pillar is to help countries strengthen their capacity to monitor and respond to the spread of the virus.

item.title: A New Predictive Model for More Accurate Electrical Grid Mapping
item.description: Challenge: When planning connectivity deployments in emerging markets, it is important to have a clear picture of where existing power lines are placed.

item.title: Estimating Access to Employment Opportunities in Dhaka, Bangladesh
item.description: Challenge: Poor transport facilities and infrastructure are a major hindrance to Bangladesh’s economic development. The road network in Dhaka is severely congested.

item.title: Tackling the Global Profitarchy–Gender and the Choice of Business Sector
item.description: Challenge: Despite significant progress in women’s educational attainment and higher female labor force participation rates in many countries, progress in closing the gender pay gap, which takes the ratio of median earnings of all women to all men, has been slow.

item.title: Why Data Partnership?
item.description: Should the private sector ever share data with the public sector, even if for public good? Well, it depends. Most of us are in agreement that when companies collect our data as a natural by-product of providing a service – like our movement data or spending patterns – the company shouldn’t sell these data to a third party for profit, especially without transparency.

item.title: Improving Road Safety in Nairobi
item.description: Challenge: Kenya has one of the highest estimated crash fatality rates worldwide but is challenged to address the problem without adequate data.

item.title: On Responsible Data Use
item.description: As we develop the Data Partnership, we have a responsibility to the people impacted by our initiative – to local governments and partners, and to our own organizations – to think about how we are collecting, using, storing, and sharing information.

item.title: Mapping Freetown Transit for Resiliency
item.description: Challenge: The resiliency of a transport network is a critical component to the stability and prosperity of a city. Freetown, prone to flooding and landslides, struggles to maintain services throughout the year.

item.title: Building Urban Resilience by Mapping Formal/Informal Transit for Freetown, Sierra Leone.
item.description: The team is receiving pro-bono data collection and processing and support from Where Is My Transport, for creating the first complete map of the Freetown transit system.

item.title: Closing the Data Gap in Bicycle Planning and Evaluation Efforts: Toolkit for Mexico City.
item.description: The team has received dockless bikeshare trip data from Mobike, which they are integrating with multiple data sources to improve planning cycling and pedestrian infrastructure.

item.title: Data Fusion for Outbreak Prediction
item.description: The team is using the Google Health Trends API, combined with data from Twitter and news APIs (Data Collaboratives covers the Google partnership) to improve prediction of outbreaks in fragile states.

item.title: Identifying Crash Hotspots in Nairobi
item.description: The team is using the Waze API to analyse user-reported crash data in Nairobi and comparing these data to official records as part of a road safety investment program.

item.title: Informing Emissions Mitigation and Livlihoods Enhancement Work in Fiji with Remote Sensing
item.description: The team is using Digital Globe data on Fiji from 2006 to 2016 to assess land use change and forestation levels.

item.title: Data Partner Lightning Talks
item.description: On February 13, 2019, the Data Partnership (formerly Data Collaboratives), for the first time, brought together Partners and staff. More than 200 colleagues joined the standing-room-only event, in person and online, learning about how private data partnerships can be made to work for public good.
